description.narrative: Capacités des agents de l’Etat et de l’administration publique dans les régions sont renforcés

Capacités des agents de l’Etat renforcés et l’administration publique dans les régions est redimensionnée et comptable de son action en vue d’une gestion publique efficace et transparente au niveau locale.
independent political entity
Accountability - local government finance
Taux d'augmentation des services offerts. Degré d'amélioration de la qualité des services offerts.

comment.narrative: Faiblesse de l'administration dans l'offre des services aux populations en quantité et en qualité suffisantes. Au niveau central la gestion budgétaire se fait sans tenir compte des règles budgétaires communautaires définies dans le cadre de l’UEMOA tandis que la gestion des agents de l’Etat n’est pas maîtrise. Les effectifs ne sont pas connus avec certitude et les salaires sont payés sans l’assurance de la présence au poste des personnes payées. La maîtrise de ce poste de dépense est d’autant plus importante que la masse salariale en Guinée-Bissau absorbe la totalité des recettes fiscales du gouvernement. Au niveau local, l’administration publique est peu présente et les régions fonctionnent au gré des situations, sans règles claires et objectifs définis. La décentralisation tant recherchée ne peut malheureusement se faire sans un minimum de déconcentration administrative et de renforcement des capacités dans la gestion et la participation locales.

description.narrative: Appui à la Réforme de l'Administration Publique, Modernisation des Services et Décentralisation.
Réfor Administrative
independent political entity
Environment - policy, planning and administration

comment.narrative: Faible capacité des agents de l'etat principalement dans l'administration, la planification, et la gestion budgetaire.

description.narrative: Support to the Consolidation of the Protected Areas System in Guinea-Bissau' s Forest Belt (PIMS 3650 BD MSP)

title.narrative: Mi-Term Evaluation of "Support to the Consolidation of a Protected Area System in Guinea-Bissau's Forest Belt"

description.narrative: Support the consolidation and expansion of Guinea-Bissau's protected area (PA) system in forestry belt at southeastern part of the country.
populated place
populated place
Environment - policy, planning and administration

comment.narrative:
1.1. L’IBAP (Institute National de la Biodiversité et Aires Protégées) ne dispose pas d’un cadre légal pour assurer l’expansion des aires protégées dans le Complexe DBT
1.2. Absence institutionnelle de l’IBAP dans les sites du projet (Complexe DBT) 1.3. 0 1.1. 0 1.2. Existence de 4 plans d’affaires préliminaires pour deux parcs côtières et deux marins 1.7. TBD 1.8. IBAP ne dispose pas d’une stratégie de financement alternatif durable du SNAP 1.9. Rapports des inventaires disponibles ; Rapport d’Etude d’impact socio-environnemental disponible ; Rapport d’examen préliminaire du site fait par le CAIA disponible ; 18 forets communautaires identifies et 16 cartographiés et en processus de formalisation. 1.4. Plan de gestion pour les sites disponible 1.5. En cours d’élaboration : six missions techniques et rapports des missions disponibles, informant sur les limites (Extension du Corridor faunistique de Salifo-Xitole); revue des études existants sur la possibilité potentiel de créations des parcs transfrontalières avec l’République de Guinée; 1.6. Plan d’affaire disponible ; Brochure en cours de finalisation. 1.7. 15 techniciens disposent et utilisent des connaissances en SIG, et 22 sur la planification stratégique ; 1.8. En cour d’élaboration et à finaliser au premier trimestre 2016 1.9. Plan de développement disponible et sa mise en œuvre à partir 2016 1.10. : Reforestation dans les deux sites ;- deux actions pour la légalisation des associations (Cuntabane e Corubal) ; Appui aux apiculteurs dans le cadre du SGP et à la transformation des produits apicoles à Cosse-Dulombi ; Plus de 200 femmes utilisent de fours améliores pour la rationalisation des bois de chauffe ; 1.11. Deux Comité ad hoc, intégrant les autorités administratives et traditionnelles, secteur privé, femmes et jeunes, mis en place assurent la cogestion 1.12. 80% des villages sensibilisées à l’intérieur des AP du site appliquent les modèles de congestion des écosystèmes 1.13. : Sept (7) Association et ONG (APILESTE, Apicultores de Canhadude, Ass. Cuntabane, Ass Corbal, Daridibó, Fonda Huuwa et de Faabade Boé) collaborent dans la gestion durable des aires protégées en appliquant le

description.narrative: To establish and operationalize terrestrial PAs in the Dulombi-BoÃ©-Tchetche (DBT) complex and thereby significantly expand and strengthen Guinea-Bissauâ€™s PA system.

comment.narrative: Classificação das AP do Complexo DBT e aumento da Cobertura do SNAP de 14,9 para 26 % do território nacional

Progress being made towards the creation “ de jure” of the protected areas within DBT Complex as follows: consolidated management structures are in place in all project sites; inventory of fauna, including forestry and aquatic avifauna, flora completed as well as the fauna and flora management plans; legal and regulatory texts discussed and approved by key actors; prior examination of the complex DBT project classification as type C carried out by CAIA (Environmental Impact Evaluation Unit); International Consultant (Firm) to carry out a study on environmental and socio-economic impact assessment of DBT parks creation selected; preliminary DBT parks management plans developed and available; strategic plan for expansion of the National Protected Area System under preparation; Business plan available; Wendo tcham lagoon designated as Humid Zone of international importance by the RAMSAR Convention.
Decréscimo da taxa de deflorestação no Complexo DBT, expresso em ha de floresta densa e de floresta aberta

DBT Complex zone completely preserved from illegal logging; 30 Village Fire Management Committees were established and are fully operational. There is also a reduced pressure on the forest from the peasants as a result of alternative sustainable solutions/technologies opportunities offered, for: (i) Rice production in swamp soils instead of upland soils by 147 peasants and their respective family members (in average, 8 per household), (ii) 247 people learned how to build improved cook stoves, most efficient in terms of energy (fuel wood) consumption/saving; (iii) Improved beekeeping techniques learnt and adopted by 120 beekeepers; (iv) Reforestation (20 ha expected more for this year) and (v) Increased awareness given to the village hunters on the damage that can result from burning land for creating new grazing land.

description.narrative: 3. The status of emblematic species such as the African elephant in the Dulombi NP and the western Chimpanzees in the BoÃ© area

comment.narrative:
According to recent survey by Chimbo Foundation, there are approximately 500 chimp individuals in the BoÃ© area.
Elephant survey will require update.
Populations of emblematic species maintained stable

Following the MTR recommendation, one indicator has been adopted: Chimpanzees. It is estimated that the current population is stable and is about 800 individuals, according to Chimbo Foundation estimates. There is a considerable increase of other primate species, and ungulates, due to considerable decrease of hunting activities in the complex as a result of the supervision by DBT Park-Guards, awareness and fear of contamination of zoonosis and in particular of the Ebola virus.
Effective compliance with the protection of wildlife is having positive effects on the growth of different species. It is observed that the elephant population is very small and given their cross-border migration it is difficult to carry out effective follow-up. Observations of other emblematic species are very frequent like the Hippo in the Corubal River and Red Antelope (Hippotragus equinus) in all DBT Complex sites. Furthermore, signs of the presence of Lions (Panthera) were also observed in Boé.

description.narrative: Immediate threats to terrestrial ecosystems mitigated through the effective expansion and management of PAs in the forest belt region
4. Increased scores on the GEF4â€™s PA Management Effectiveness Tracking Tool â€œMETTâ€? for all five target sites within the DBT Complex

comment.narrative:
[1] Dulombi NP 19
[2] BoÃ© NP 20
[3] Cuntabane-Quebo Corr. 19
[4] Salifo Corridor 19
[5] Tchetche Corridor 21

All scores are 30 by the MTE
All scores are 40 by end of project

According to the METT criterion as defined in the project document, the score below shows that there is improvement in the management of the DBT Complex.
The METT values continue improving within the DBT Complex, and the biggest threats are being efficiently managed by the project sites management structure, actively presents in the project sites with high support of the key local actors (farmers, hunters, traditional chiefs, CBOs leaders and local administrative officials). The increase in the awareness of these project partners/beneficiaries has contributed for the conservation of PA forest ecosystems (its fauna and flora) by mobilizing communities against illegal logging and encouraging its members to abandon/reduce slash and burn practices for agriculture purpose, use of fire in traditional beekeeping and harmful illegal hunting (poisoning animals, burn forest to stimulate grass regeneration). Furthermore, this has contributed for controlling new settlements within the PAs for a minimal level in the buffer zones of the parks from migration of people from across the border. Although the Angolan bauxite mining concession is outside the proposed PAs, there is still a concern about the impacts of transporting the ore via rail or road through the Cuntabane-Quebo Wildlife Corridor to the Buba sea port for export and the impacts of future mining activities on the watershed of the Corubal River Basin, critical to the region. The modification of the natural ecosystem by fires of different origins persists but in minor scale. The causes of the fires are being actively discussed, and the measures widely disseminated through socio-professional associations/CBOs of farmers and hunters, youths and women covering all the extent of the DBT Complex. Evasive species, pollution and major geological events (except for the siltation of some rivers, streams and springs) are unknown. Best traditional conservation management practices are being revitalized with the support of village community volunteers, leaders and authorities.
Dulombi: 65
Boé: 62
Tche-tche: 61
Cuntabane-Quebo: 61
Salifo-Xitole: 60
Average: 61,6

description.narrative: Improved systemic and institutional capacity provides the enabling framework for establishing and managing a more representative PA network.
5. Increased scores on the UNDPâ€™s Capacity Development Scorecard for Protected Areas Management over the baseline

comment.narrative:
Systemic 14 / 30 (44%)
Institutional 24 / 45 (54%)
Individual 10 / 21 (46%)
(General avg. 49%)
Scores, expressed in absolute terms, increase by at least 20%

The Capacity Development Scorecard (CDS) tool measure the improvement of the capacities of the actors involved in the management of the PA. It has been applied in the formulation of the project in 2009. It takes into account the systemic level (DBT complex as a whole), the institutional level (entities involved), and the individual level. During the project Mid-Term Evaluation exercise, the CDS has been applied to measure the evolution in the development of capacity-building since the launch of the project. The results of the mid-term evaluation are: systemic 20/30 (64%) Institutional 29/45 (63%) Individual 10/21 (52%) (Average general 61%). While training needs assessment has not been performed at the start of the project, the current technical, human and logistic capacities of IBAP have been strengthened. IBAP’s cadres have benefitted from relevant training provided on PA management, SIG, strategic planning, micro projects formulation, PA creation process that contributed to increase their awareness and capacity to fulfil their duties. According to the MTR report, efforts have to be dedicated in upgrading the staff technical capacity for which a capacity development plan must be prepared and implemented. In addition to that, development of sustainable mechanism of financing the National Protected Area System management cost must be ensured.

description.narrative: 6. Results from the application of UNDPâ€™s Financial Sustainability Scorecard

comment.narrative: Total Score for PA System = 40 out of a total possible score of 197 (i.e. 20%)
Scores, expressed in absolute terms, increase by at least 30%

The financial sustainability scorecard (FSC) measures the financial sustainability of the management of the PA. It was applied in 2009 to the National system of protected (SNAP) areas during the project document formulation (at the same time as the METT). It was revised in June 2012, and then in 2014. The mid-term evaluation team has analyzed all of the FSC made by the various IBAP projects. The scores obtained differs much from one to the other FSC. The team concluded that IBAP’s need to harmonize its monitoring system at a centralized level (e.g. at level of IBAP financial unit) in order to have a more credible consolidated tool.
The results of the mid-term evaluation are: total score of 74 out 220, or 34%.

description.narrative: Participatory conservation management approaches in the DBT Complex are implemented.

7. Communitiesâ€™ perception of their livelihood stake in the good stewardship of biological resources in the DBT Complex, measured through the periodic and independent application of the â€˜Most Significant Changeâ€™ (MSC) technique.

comment.narrative:
Not Applicable
The MSC technique is to be applied once the project has been launched and some form of change has occurred. The baseline corresponds to all assessments that corroborate the situation analysis for this project, particularly with respect to land-uses and livelihoods.
Changes in livelihoods are perceived through the independent application of the MSC technique

Through the MSC, it was verified improvement in the perception that the ”parks are with and for the populations" to decide on the rights of use and access in the areas of sustainable development within the Park; it’s important to reinforce their traditional social mechanisms of control and management of space and natural resources, as well as taking into account their heritage, knowledge, norms and cultural practices regarding management of the PA of the DBT complex; the information, awareness and training of policy makers provided have led to a positive change in perception of the role and function of the protected areas in biodiversity conservation for economic and socio-cultural activities support, climate change mitigation, food security and poverty reduction.

description.narrative: Project in Support of Electoral Cycles 2010-2012 in the African Portuguese Speaking Counties (PALOP) and Timor Leste
Support to 2010-13 electoral cycles in Guinea Bissau through targeted support and capacity development provided to electoral processes and EMBs, elected MPs, Parliaments and media.
independent political entity
Elections - elections
Strengthening adaptive capacity and resilience to Climate Change in the Agrarian and Water Resources Sectors in Guinea-Bissau (PIMS 3977)-FSP

title.narrative: Climate change PRODOC page of signature
Evaluation à mi-parcours du projet «Renforcement de la résilience et la capacité d'adaptation des secteurs agraires et hydriques au changement climatique»

description.narrative: Guinea-Bissau's agrarian and water sectors resilience and daptive capacity to climate change stregnthgened at national, regional and community levels (14 villages with 11,000 inhabitants).
independent political entity
Energy - policy, planning and administration

comment.narrative: 1.1. Currently, only agency (Secretariat of State for Environment) 1.2. Climate change is not incorporated into the development and implementation of policies, plans, strategies, programmes, projects and initiatives that related, in different ways, to the management of natural resources. 1.3. The capacity of stakeholders to adapt to climate change is not being developed. Climate change risks and vulnerability in Guinea-Bissau are both poorly understood and poorly quantified concepts. 1.4. Current systems to forecast climate change are low resolution for Guinea-Bissau, meaning that information is not fine-grained enough to be very useful for those in a position to drive policy in the short-medium term 1.5. No climate change sustainable financing strategy exist 2.1. Regional administrations do not have information, capacity, finance or skill to address climate change. 2.2. Lack of water points and practice of best water management techniques 2.3. Appropriate climate change adaptive techniques (resilient and adaptive technologies) in agricultural production management are not known at community level in Easter part of GB. 2.4. Livestock production is severely affected by lack of pasture and water during the dry season months, thus forcing the cattle breeders to migrate with their animals far from their villages in the search of fresh natural pasture and water point (practice of transhumance) from January to June each year. 3.1. Absence of a climate change forum with multiples stakeholders engaged in the promotion of climate change adaptive and resilient techniques in rural areas. 3.2. No local strategy exist for the scaling up of all climate change adaptive measures in the Eastern Region of Gabu. 3.3. Absence of climate change knowledge and best practices sharing among local partners, international agencies and scientific community on Climate

Target 1.1.1 : quatre (4) agences ayant de capacité d’identifier et gérer les risques climatiques et la vulnérabilité, de planifier et implémenter les mesures d’adaptation dans les secteurs agraire et hydrique. Target 1.1.2.: 40 cadres techniques de ÍNM-GB disposent de connaissances sur gestion de base de données climatiques et assistance météorologique. Target 1.1.3. Une bibliothèque sur CC existe. Target 1.2.1. 20 cadres des ministères clés maîtrisent la méthodologie d’UNDP sur l’intégration de CC dans les documents de politique. Target 1.2.2 : Un document de politique agraire intégrant la gestion des risques climatiques. Target 1.3.1. 0 Target 1.3.2. 0 Target 1.3.3. Plus d’un (1) programme IEC (2015) et respectif outils de communication sont disponibles et mise en œuvre. Target 1.4.1. 0 Target 1.4.3. 28 farmers refreshed on the use of pluviometers Target 1.4.4. Un Lab. SIG au sein du MADR/SEAT mise en place pour opérationnaliser les cartes agro-climatiques et de vulnérabilité Target 1.5.1. Deux notes informatiques sur les sources de financements vertes fournissent au gouvernement Target 2.3.2. 50 paysans répliquent des techniques agricoles d’adaptations plus résilientes aux CCs. Target 2.3.3. 1 mini-barrage (Bajocunda) et 1 bassin de rétention des eaux pluviales (Camadjaba) disponibles. Target 2.3.4. 20 champs de forages établis; 150 ha des bas-fonds réhabilités; 5ha des champs de multiplication des semences installés; 6ha de sols dégradés restaurés; Target 2.3.5: Two (2) farmers’ cooperative set up Target 2.4.1: 500 cattle breeders Target 2.4.2. Plus de 20 infrastructures de stockage des fourrages construits Target 2.5.1. Key climate risks management measures agreed to promote under the MoU with agrarian and water regional structures in the Gabu Region implemented; Target 3.1.2: Trois (3) guides de bonnes pratiques disponibles Target 3.1.3. Un forum rural fonctionnel (au moins 4 réunions régulières par an). Target 3.2.1: Une stratégie pour la durabilité

Indicateur 1.1.1 : Nombre de agences ayant de capacité d’identifier et gérer les risques climatiques et la vulnérabilité, de planifier et implémenter les mesures d’adaptation dans les secteurs agraire et hydrique. - Four agences (INM-GB, INPA, DGE, DGA) ont accrue leur capacité en matière d’identification et gestion des risques climatiques et de la vulnérabilité, ainsi de planifier et mise en œuvre des mesures d’adaptation. - Gabu synoptic meteorological station resume functions and now is providing regular and timely agro-meteorological information to the farmers in the Easter Region, by with support of 28 farmers’ pluviometers operators (50% females). Indicateur 1.1.2. : Nombre de cadres et collaborateurs des agences clés ayant des connaissances en collecte, traitement et diffusion des informations météorologiques; - 52 technical staff of the INMGB (14 were women) have increased their knowledge and skills on collecting, processing and disseminating meteorological information. - 28 farmers (50% female) collaborators of National Institute of Meteorology have refreshed their skills in the use of farmers pluviometers and on how compile and interpret rainfall data collected regarding provision of guidance on the best moment for crops planting within their respective communities. Indicateur 1.1.3. Existence d’une bibliothèque et manuels de formation portant publications sur Changements Climatiques. - Provided an office for the installation of a specialized library on climate change at the Secretariat of State for Environment; - Reviewed the bibliographic collection of GIDEA/SEA - Office of Information, Documentation, Environmental Education/Secretariat of State for Environment - Survey and cataloguing of selected literature by 4 GIDEA/SEA staff is ongoing to create a database in Access format. Indicateur 1.2.1 : Nombre de cadres des agences partenaires qui ont acquis des connaissances sur la méthodologie d’intégration du changement climatique dans les processus nat

description.narrative: To increase resilience and enhance key adaptive capacity to address the additional risks posed by climate change to water and agriculture sectors in Guinea- Bissau
1. High level policies and management plans relating to agriculture and water sectors explicitly consider climate change risks and opportunities

comment.narrative:
The following policies / plans are not climate-proof:
*National Plan of Agricultural Investment (PNIA)
*National Program on Food Security
*Water Directive / Water Code
*Poverty Reduction Strategy II

At least two high level policies (National Plan for Agricultural Investimment, Region Gabu Local Plan Development, Water and Sanitation Policies, National Plan Livestock development) / management plans explicitly consider climate change risks and opportunities.

. Significant progress has been made towards the achievement of this DO target: (i) 40 keys cadres from 16 keys line ministers have acquired knowledge on climate change mainstreaming methodology and have actively participated in the application of the methodology, integrating CC issues into the target policy documents and plans (Agricultural Development Policy Letter; Water and Sanitation Master Plan; Livestock Development Policy Letter; National Strategy for Poverty Reduction and Gabu Region Local Development Plans (Piche and Pirada administrative sectors). These documents have been revised integrating climate changes issues, following the validation workshops held in Bissau and Gabu. Is expected that by the end of the year this policy documents and plans will be adopted by the Government.

description.narrative: 2.Government and international funding allocated to managing climate change risks increased

comment.narrative: <25,000 USD/year
At least 100,000 USD/year

The project team (National Project Coordinator, Agricultural Specialist and Climate Change Adaptation Specialist) has provided assistance to the Government in its partnership with: (a) West African Development Bank (BOAD) for a project proposal formulation on climate change adaptation in amount of 10,000,000 USD to the Board of Adaptation Fund before end of the year; (b) European Union (under Global Climate Changes Alliance-GCCA funding) for formulation of project proposal on adaptation and mitigation to climate in order to strengthen the resilience of communities of the Bafatá, Gabu, Quinara and Tombali regions. This project is in its final stage and the planned funding are of 4 million euros and is virtually guaranteed. This project, will strengthen the adaptation initiatives envisaged under the current NAPA-Resilience project in the Gabu region.
UNDP CO and Regional Technical Advisor have provided technical support to the Government in the elaboration of a 12.5 million USD project proposal on climate change adaptation in coastal area and a 5 million USD project proposal on early warning system development. The adaptation project was approved but as LDCF is exhaust, therefore these two projects are under reformulation seeking GCF funding.
Within the framework of partnership with the Directorate General of Livestock, the Government through Monetary Union of West Africa (UEMOA) has provided 25,000 USD for the vaccination of cattle against carbuncle hematic and symptomatic. Also, under the same framework, 25,000 USD were invested in the construction of 4 veterinary clinics, 1 small slaughterhouse and 1 butcher shop in some of the project targeted villages in Gabu Region.
These two initiatives will support the achievement of the target under this DO.

description.narrative: 3. Scores of UNDP\\\'s Vulnerability Reduction Assessment (VRA) to be applied upon inception, mid-term and end-of-project in project-site communities

comment.narrative: As of results after the application of the tool at project inception
Aggregate reduction of 10-35%

The exposure to the risks are the same but the vulnerability of the communities has decreased thanks to increase of awareness on climate change issues and the adoption of sustainable solutions/technologies such as cereal banks, fodder plants cultivation, resilient agricultural techniques, improved wells for water adduction/pumping, etc. during the reporting period, the following has contributed for strengthening the communities resilience to climate change: (i) draft report identifying keys national actors suitable to address climate risks management and proposing a Commitment Plan for climate risks management to be signed by all of them is available; (ii) 10 Contingencies Plans for 10 villages are developed and adopted; (iii) four (4) national technicians have acquired knowledge on climate change risks and vulnerability analysis and mainstreaming methodology through a training course provided by a Burkina Faso Specialized Training Institute; (v) the Rural Forum on Climate Change and the Environmental Surveillance Committee has met quarterly and promoted awareness campaigns on Ebola Virus Disease, deforestation implications in climate change, need to preserve their natural heritage through a participatory and holistic approach.

description.narrative: Climate change risks and adaptation measures integrated into key national policies, plans and programs for water, agriculture and livestock resource management.
1. High level policies and management plans relating to agriculture and water sectors explicitly consider climate change risks and opportunities

comment.narrative:
The following policies / plans are not climate-proof:
*National Plan of Agricultural Investment (PNIA)
*National Program on Food Security
*Water Directive / Water Code
*Poverty Reduction Strategy II
At least two policy frameworks relevant for the agriculture and water sectors effectively incorporate climate risk consideration and adaptation measures

This DO is in good trend for its accomplishement: 40 national technicians from key ministries trained on UNDP climate change mainstreaming methodology; revised and preliminary mainstreamed climate change issues into Agricultural Development Policy Letter, Water and Sanitation Master Plan, Livestock Development Policy Letter, and Gabu Region Local Development Plans (Pitche and Pirada administrative Sectors). 239 students from different schools in Gabu region sensitized on climate change issues.

description.narrative: 2. Number of key agencies having taken institutional measures to respond to climate change through capacity building and mainstreaming activities

comment.narrative: Currently, only SEADD - hence 1 agency
MADR, MEIRN NMI has the capability and enhanced implementation and planning of the program and projects on climate change

The project support to the Government has contributed to (i) strengthen the capacity of the National Institute of the Meteorology (INM-GB) in the field of data processing and dissemination of meteorological information, (ii) improve INM-GB capacity to provide meteorological assistance supportive to various social and economic activities, namely agricultural production activities (iii) enable NIM-GB, to participate and profit from the World Meteorological Monitoring programme (VMM) and (iv) create a scientific basis for an early warning system development, (v) two (2) NIM-GB cadres trained in Praia (Cape Verde) on Geographical Information Systems to strengthen the GIS Laboratory in process of operationalization. This Laboratory also has received too equipments from the SEMA (System of Environmental Monitoring in Africa) Project in complementary basis.

description.narrative: 3. Percentage of end users utilizing climate risk information from seasonal climate forecast systems in decision-making.

comment.narrative: No current seasonal climate forecast system is in place. Once in place for at least 6 months, a baseline in terms of potential and actual end-users will be set
Results of the seasonal forecast and its integration into farming practices are available

Synoptic and climatological stations of Bafata and Gabu inaugurated
Response kits delivered to operationalize of contingency plans in 10 villages, project sites
The pluviómetre peasants continue to play their roles, giving relevant information to farmers about the soil humidity.
Two local community radios continue to emit radio programs about meteorological information. The "Radio Sol Mansi" with national coverage has issued awareness programs "radio nóvelas" in three national languages (creolo, fula and mandinga), in order to sensitize the general population about causes, consequence, climate change impacts and adaptation measures.
A total of 10 Contingency Plans were prepared for 10 villages. Were delivered the kits for rapid response for the implementation of Contingency Plans in these 10 villages.
Performed more than 10 (ten) awareness campaigns in which they were sensitized about 400 people in villages on the operationalization of the Contingency Plans drawn up in 10 villages of the project whose objective aims to train teams to answer the possible calamities of natural disasters;
Formed 19 literacy teachers and animators, among which 2 are women, about the use and implementation of literacy teachers manual; Literate of literacy participants in 14 project villages sites were 331 (214 are women) on different themes; Conducted and presented a theatrical piece (play) about the problems of climate change and mitigation measures in the 9th FRAC session;

description.narrative: Small and medium scale climate change adaptation practices for agriculture, water and livestock resource management are demonstrated and implemented in selected regions
1. Average agricultural productivity of key crops (kg / ha), measured at site level in pilot demonstration fields - showing improvements compared to national and/or regional average for GabÃº

comment.narrative: National and/or regional (GabÃº) average agricultural productivity for key crops to be applied as baseline for comparison
Increased the average yield of cereal crops dried (sorghum, black corn, corn Bacillus, etc.) approximately 200 kg /ha; pam-pam and bas fond rice of approximately 200-300 kg /ha

Formed 44 people (22 women and 22 men) of the Management Committee of water points in 11 locations. Built 6 drinking water supply wells; 6 animators trained in the techniques of determination of crop yields through square installation. Animators have used this knowledge in installing 53 square in 53 agricultural fields. Of these 17 were cultivated fields of traditional form and remaining through new techniques. Initiated the hidro-agricola management in Padjama, Canquelifa, Iancor, Cuntim; Formed and recycled a total of 361 farmers in agricultural producers about the cultural climate resilient techniques, of which 58 are women about 32.58%. Have been installed 30 demonstration fields practice (0.25 x 0.25 ha) being 13 of Zaï, 10 of crop rotation and 7 transverse field. The average yields were 2348 kg/ha for rice; 1293 kg/ha for corn. 1572 kg/ha black maize and 940 kg/ha for peanuts; Conducted 5 awareness-raising campaigns and information to communities about the use of excreta for the production of organic fertilizers and producing alternative energy source. In this campaign form 150 people that sensitized 80 are women. Trained 183 farmers in climate change resilient techniques. Finished the stake of approximately 546 hectares of land to practice agriculture; Sensitized 1350 new cattle breeders , in which 619 are women on the importance of brachiaria cultivation

description.narrative: 2. Food security in pilot villages as a result of the effective uptake of technologies and techniques introduced by the project

comment.narrative: As per WFP data for selected villages among target sites
Guaranteed food availability / increased by at least two more months

Finalized the construction of 8 seeds/cereal banks with a storage capacity of 25 tons each, in 8 villages (Cuntim, Camalidja, Padjama, Canquelifa, Bajocunda, Patchana, and Copa Mangui) for storage of cereals and seeds;Sensitized 743 creators of cattle, of which 125 are women, about animal nutrition and importance of hangars; Formed 55 creators of cattle on the family cattle management; Formed 100 creators in animal housing techniques, its advantage in dairy and meat production; Built 23 hangars with storage capacity of 32.77 ton (1.425 ton/hangar) for storage of hay for livestock feed in the critical period (February to June), being 16 in 14 projects villages and 7 in the neighbouring villages; Harvested 600 kg of seeds of brachiaria in 27 fields installed the 24 villages are very common; Collected 50000 kg of dry straw of brachiaria in 27 fields and stored in hangars; 7000 kg of dry straw harvested and stored in hangars built for the purpose; Produced and distributed 6 tons of organic fertilizer (1.2 tonnes per village) by bovine waste recovery;

description.narrative: 3. Water availability at the level of households that are benefitting from pilot measures to improve water management (litres / day / inhabitant over time)

comment.narrative: Not available - target households for improved water management are not yet established
Availability of 20 liters of water / head / day over time)

Inhabitants of 14 villages, project sites, have access to clean drinking water by building 14 water points (11 modern and improved wells 3 holes). This water availability is extensible to the animals that they have water in quantity and quality, thereby improving the public health situation. All these 14 villages have management committees of water spots composed essentially by women.

description.narrative: Lessons learned and best practices from pilot activities are disseminated, and integrated in national plans and policies.
1. Percentage of stakeholders being targeted for awareness-raising activities affirming ownership of adaptation processes

comment.narrative: N/A - stakeholders to be targeted for awareness-raising activities will be defined upon inception
50% over the baseline

The synergy with other projects involved area could be bring more impact, change and transformation in communities to strengthen their adaptive capacity to adverse effects of climate change; To maximize use of the holes is required near the holes are constructed with the respective troughs to serve not only for human consumption but also for animal; Given the financial difficulties widely known an important lesson was taken: the will to continue to work , prepare documents required for achieving the objectives set for the various products; It is possible to save, capitalize upon the financial resources of the projects, as well as expand the area of ??competence of the same , by creating synergy with other project stakeholders which would be beneficial for the people; The successful introduction of new technologies in agriculture depends on the strategy used, that is, must be accompanied by incentives to the agricultural inputs and materials; There is a great desire on the part of peasants trained to replicate the new techniques of resilient adaptation to climate. The need to expand the tuning fork of new technologies in the agricultural sector (agriculture, livestock and water management ) for farmers and creators of the project area and surrounding. This extension depends on the strategy used, that is, must be accompanied by incentives to the agricultural inputs and materials.

description.narrative: 2. Number of contributions to the Adaptation Learning Mechanism (ALM)

comment.narrative: 2 per year

With the constant updating and improving the project Web site interface (www.alteracoesclimaticas-gb.org), the establishment of the first BO, they were distributed 1000 copies whose contents causes and consequences of climate change and mitigation measures of its effects , and the issuance of radio novel and radio programs of the project, the project communities begin to learn best resilient adaptation techniques to climate change and now have information on the benefits of its application. They are shared several success stories both in terms of agriculture as the feed level ( e.g. introduction of forage spices - . Brachiaria ). Several success stories are filmed and will soon be made ??available to UNDP.

comment.narrative: 0 ha of rice field rehabilitated. Rice productivity of 700-1000 kg/ha. 0 rice mills and rice peeling machines used by beneficiaries. 0 beneficiaries have knowledge of how to use rice transformation equipment. 0 storage facilities. 0 carriages (to transport agricultural products from villages to local markets.)

Output 2: 300ha of rice fields (200 ha in mangrove and 100 ha in bas-fond ecosystem) rehabilitated and 16 associations strengthened. Output 4: 4.1. Increase in 15% the amount of processed agricultural products. 4.2. Study cost / benefit mills and peelers in 24 partner villages 4.3. 24 associations with women trained and using the meat and fish conservation technique. 4.4. 3 pilot villages with the field of sustainable and low cost way poultry production techniques, they will be the starting point for the other 21 tabancas as providers of poultry for breeding. Output 4: 4.1. 480 women able to read and write 4.2. 24 associations able to continue the literacy courses in its community and assuming the costs of teacher´s payment 4.3. 24 associations strengthen in financial management techniques / Accounting

Output 2: 565.35ha or rice fields (525.10 ha in mangrove and 40.25ha in bas-fond ecosystem) rehabilitated and 16 associations strengthned. Output 4: 4.1. 50% less than the previous year due to a malfunction of some equipment and the low productivity of rice. The amount of processed agricultural products were 20 tons. 4.2. Practically, all mills in Biombo Region are underused. In Oio region only 3 villages are not using with desired frequency. Hence 11 villages in the Bafata and Oio intervention areas will be covered after diet analysis, grain production, sale in local market, sustainability and strengthened association. 4.3. 24 associations and 120 women trained in the conservation techniques of agricultural (fruits and vegetables) and livestock products. 4.4. 3 hen houses are still in construction phase due to delays in the procurement process. Purchases of genetically improved roosters were made. As a counterpart each village are now adding 75 chickens for breeding. Output 5 5.1. 960 women able to read and write 5.2. 24 associations able to continue the literacy courses in their respectivy community are assuming the costs of teacher´s payment 5.3. 0 associations. The accounting consultant are still under procurement process

description.narrative: Strengthening capacity of Elections Management Bodies over the electoral cycle
independent political entity

1) Elections Générales sont organisées de façon efficace et dans les délais accordées par les acteurs politiques nationaux, dans le cadre du calendrier de la transition politique ; (2) Les élections sont considérées libres, transparente et justes par les MOE et acteurs politiques nationaux.

comment.narrative: Après le coup militaire du 12 avril 2012 qui a interrompu les élections présidentielles du 12 mars 2012 empêchant l’élection du président de la république de façon démocratique, le pays a entamé à nouveau une période de transition politique. Cette période doit s’achevée avec des élections libres et justes avant la fin de 2013. Par accord politique et tenant compte de la fin du mandat de la CNE, un nouvel secrétariat exécutif de la CNE vient d’être élu et n’a pas beaucoup d’expérience dans le domaine électoral. Des formations de mise à niveau en administration électoral ont été conçues et délivrées aux membres du secrétariat. Le calendrier électoral est très serré et il y un risque de dérapage du calendrier. La mobilisation des ressources est toujours reste en-deça des besoins et un effort additionnel de la part des partenaires s’impose.

policy, planning and administration

1- Existence des rapports périodiques de suivi du PIP. 2- Existence du Plan Stratégique Opérationnel 3- Existence du document final sur le Stratégie National de Développent de Statistique (SNDS). 4- Existence de rapport d‘enquêtes l'Index Harmonisé des Prix Industriel (IHPI) et l'Index Harmonisé des Prix aux Consommateurs (IHPC) 5- Disponibilité d’une politique fiscale 6- Existence d’un modèle de projection Macroéconomique 7- Nombre des cadres disposant des capacités en Gestion Axés sur le Résultats (GAR), Suivi et Evaluation (S&E) et production des rapports 8- Existence d’un outil moderne de gestion pour la coordination de l’aide

comment.narrative: 1- 01 rapport de Suivi & Evaluation PIP disponible 2- 01 document de la Plan Stratégique Opérationnel «Terra Ranka» est disponible 3- 01 document de la Stratégie National de Développement de la Statistique est validé. 4- 02 rapports sur l’IHPI et l’IHPC sont disponibles et validés. 5- 01 document de politique fiscale est disponible 6- 01 modèle de projection Macroéconomique est disponible. 7- 100 cadres disposent de compétence dans les domaines de la Gestion Axés sur le Résultats (GAR), Suivi et Evaluation (S&A) et production de rapports. 8 -01 plateforme de gestion de l'aide au développement (PGA) est actualisée et fonctionnel.

1- Deux rapports trimestriels de suivi du PIP fait, le troisième est cours. 2- Le Plan Stratégique Opérationnel ‘Terra Ranka’ est déjà disponible en français et anglais 3- Document de la Stratégie National de Développement de la Statistique est disponible et validé. 4 – 02 rapports sur l’IHPC sont déjà validés et disponibles. Les rapports sur l’IHPI ne sont pas faits 5- mission d’appui du Pole de Dakar à la DGI (fiches action du cadre stratégique). Visite ENA sur l´ouverture de formation sur la Fiscalité. 6- Le modèle de projection macroéconomique est en cours 7- 60 cadres ont des compétences en Gestion Axé sur les Résultats (GAR) 8- Le développement de la plateforme est en cours et va continuer en 2016

description.narrative: Renforcement des capacités de décideurs politiques et cadres techniques ; Mécanisme de coordination intersectorielle ; Capacités d'OSC renforcées sur la gestion des ressources naturelles ; Plateforme nationale en gestion des ressources naturelles
capital of a political entity

activity-description.narrative: Le pays entire car les décideurs politiques et les cadres au niveau national seront formés. Les cadres de Bafatá, Gabú et Quinara sont ciblés au niveau régional. Les OCB et ONG nationales et régionales seront impliquées. La plupart d'activités se tiendront à Bissau.

description.narrative: Energy - policy, planning and administration

Indicateur 1.1 : Nombre de décideurs politiques (HF) ayant des connaissances sur la gestion des ressources naturelles renouvelables et non renouvelables Indicateur 1.2 : Nombre de cadres (H/F) disposant des connaissances scientifiques, juridiques et commerciales sur la gestion durable des ressources naturelles. Indicateur 1.3 : Pourcentage de cadres formés estimant accomplir efficacement leur fonction qu’avant la formation.
Indicateur 2.1: Existence d’un mécanisme de coordination intersectorielle. Indicateur 2.2: Taux de participation des institutions aux réunions de coordination. Indicateur 2.3 : Existence d’une étude sur le genre et la gestion des ressources naturelles bissau-guinéennes. Indicateur 2.4 : Existence d’une ébauche de carte hydrogéologique. Indicateur 2.5 : – Nombre de cadres (H/F) qui reçoivent les manuels d’évaluation d’impact environnemental révisés.
Indicateur 3.1 : Pourcentage de la population (H/F) touchée par les programmes radiophoniques. Indicateur 3.2 : Pourcentage de la population (H/F) disposant des informations et des connaissances sur la gestion durable des ressources naturelles.
Indicateur 4.1 : Existence d’une plateforme nationale pour la promotion de la gestion durable des ressources naturelles renouvelables et non renouvelables

comment.narrative:
Point de référence 1.1 : Faibles connaissances scientifiques, juridiques et commerciales des décideurs politiques. Point de reference 1.2 : Faible connaissance des cadres. Point de référence 1.3 : Faible connaissance des cadres.
Point de référence 2.1 : Inexistence de mécanisme de coordination intersectorielle. Point de référence 2.2 : ND. Point de référence 2.3 : Inexistence d’étude sur le genre et la gestion des ressources naturelles. Point de référence 2.4 : Inexistence de carte hydrogéologique. Point de référence 2.5 : Manuels existent mais nécessite une révision.
Point de reference 3.1 : Inexistence de programme sur la gestion durable des ressources naturelles. Point de reference 3.2 : Faible connaissance de la population sur la gestion durable des ressources naturelles.
Point de référence 4.1 : Inexistence de plateforme nationale.

Cible 1.1 : – 10 membres de la Primature ; – 30 membres de l’Assemblé nationale populaire ; – 10 membres de la Commission spécialisée pour l’agriculture, les ressources naturelles et l’environnement. CIble 1.2 : – 15 cadres de la CAIA et du SEAT ; – 15 cadres de la DGFF. Cible 1.3 : 60% des cadres formés.
Cible 2.1 : Document de politique national sur l'environnement et le développement durable disponible. Cible 2.2 : Mécanisme de coordination intersectorielle disponible. Cible 2.3: 60% des institutions invitées. Cible 2.4 : Une étude sur le genre et la gestion des ressources naturelles bissau-guinéennes disponible. Cible 2.5 : Une ébauche de carte hydrogéologique disponible. Cible 2.6 : Chaque manuel reçus par trente cadres. Cible 2.7 : Réglementation de la loi de base sur l'environnement disponible.
Cible 3.1 : 30% dans chaque région ciblée. Cible 3.2: 30% dans chaque région ciblée.
Cible 4.1 : Une plateforme nationale pour la promotion de la gestion durable des ressources naturelles renouvelables et non renouvelables disponible

Cible 1.1 : - 80 membres de l'Assemblée nationale populaire. Cible 1.2 : - 20 cadres de la CAIA et du SEAT. Cible 1.3 : 20% des cadres.
Cible 2.1 : Document de politique national sur l'environnement et le développement durable indisponible. Cible 2.2 : Mécanisme de coordination intersectorielle indisponible. Cible 2.3: 0% des institutions invitées. Cible 2.4 : Une étude sur le genre et la gestion des ressources naturelles bissau-guinéennes indisponible. Cible 2.5 : Une ébauche de carte hydrogéologique indisponible. Cible 2.6 : Aucun manuel reçu par trente cadres. Cible 2.7 : Réglementation provisoire de la loi de base sur l'environnement disponible.

title.narrative: Local governance and economic development project

description.narrative: The objective of this project is to enhance the capacity of national, regional and pre-municipalities authorities and to reinforce a inclusive and participatory planning in order to improve food security and reduce poverty.

title.narrative: Creating the conditions for local governance and local development in Guinea Bissau
LD Cover Page version 2 General Revision 1

description.narrative: This joint UNDP-UNCDF programme aims to create the conditions for decentralization in Guinea Bissau building on lessons learned from the PADDL project.
Accountability - local government finance

1.1. Existence of Regional and Local Development Plans of Gabu, Cacheu and Quinara Regions not updated for decade and not operationally endorsed by both Regional Government 1.2. Number of pre-municipalities administrative managers who have skills on decentralization, local development planning, budgeting and management 1.3. Number of communication strategy to support civic campaign formulated and implemented 1.4. Number of people affected by the awareness campaign on accountability, transparency 1.5. Number of CRDs and CSDs revitalized and/or created with active participation of women 1.6. Existence of a diagnostic study on the potential of each target region 1.7. Number of audits to assess the economic, fiscal, and organizational functioning of pre-municipalities and set-up local conferences to validate the audit and its action plan 2.1. Existence of region office functional in the target region 2.2. Existence of an ENA rehabilitated and trainers empowered to become change agents and leaders of the reform processes of local development in the regions 2.3. Number of administrative civil servants in Gabu, Cacheu and Quinara who have skills in planning, data collection and analysis 3.1. Number of survey conducted in target regions 3.2. Number of LED strategy available in the target regions 3.3. % delivery against approved budget

comment.narrative: 1.1. Existence of Regional and Local Development Plans of Gabu, Cacheu and Quinara Regions not updated for decade and not operationally endorsed by both Regional Government 1.2. Weak capacity of local authorities (human nor financial) to support quality service delivery and local development. 1.3. Absence of communication strategy to support civic campaign formulated and implemented 1.4. No awareness realized on accountability and transparency in the target regions 1.5. 1 CRD in Gabu 1.6. No LoOking diagnostic 1.7. Zero audit assessment 2.1. Region office in Gabu, Cacheu and Quinara are weak and not functional 2.2. ENA exists but it does not have training modules 2.3. TBD 3.1. No survey conducted in target regions 3.2. No LED strategy available in the target regions 3.3. 0 delivery

1.1. 1 RDP participatory updated, endorsed by local authorities and keys stakeholders; Five sectorial development plans, participatory updated, endorsed, and available 1.2. 50 pre-municipalities administrative managers trained on decentralization policy, local development planning, budgeting and management. 1.3. 1 communication strategy to support civic campaign formulated and implemented 1.4. 100 people participated in awareness campaigns 1.5. 1 CRD in Gabu revitalized, 1 CRD in each other target region created (Quinara and Cacheu) 2.1. 1 per region (2015) 2.2. 1 ENA capacity in providing courses on decentralization policy and local management strengthened 2.3. 50 administrative civil servants in Gabu, Cacheu and Quinara 3.1. 1 per region 3.2. 1 per region (2015) 3.3. 80%

1.1. 0 RPD and SPD updated due to delays in CTA recruitment process 1.2. 0 pre-municipalities administrative managers trained due to the absence of the officers in the regional. By the end of the report, the Secretariat of State of Planning announced that they would be allocated to their regions from October this year. 1.3. 0 communication strategy plan due to absence of CTA to provide guidance. 1.4. 0 due to absence of strategy communication plan. 1.5. 0 CDR revitalized or created due to absence of the administrative officers in the region 2.1. 0 the computers and other equipment are under procurement process 2.2. 0 the dialogue with ENA was not started due to the absence of CTA. 2.3. 0 administrative civil servants trained due to the the absence of the officers in the regional. By the end of the report, the Secretariat of State of Planning announced that they would be allocated to their regions from October this year. 3.1. 0 the survey was not perfomed because the Secretariat of State of Planning informed that there is a project conducting this survey in some regions. The objective is to use the same metodology and apply it to LED Program target regions in the first quarter of 2016. 3.2. 0 LED strategy available. It requires the survey and stakeholder participation. 3.3. 6%

title.narrative: Strengthening National PA System in Guinea-Bissau

description.narrative: The project will support the capitalization of biodiversity Trust Fund Bioguine Foundation and IBAP to effectively manage the National Protected Area System, particularly the management of the Castanhez National Park.

A sustainable financial mechanism will be in place supporting the National Protected Area System and IBAP's capacity to effectively manage the Cantanhez National Park will be reinforced through a comprehensive capacity development program implementation.
Energy - policy, planning and administration

1.1 Existence de staff support et les lignes directrices pour le développement administratif et opérationnel 1.2 Existence d’un mécanisme d’audit et reportage transparent et internationalement reconnus de la FBG. 1.3 Pourcentage d’augmentation de fonds de collectes par la fondation bio guinée 1.4 Existence de dotation de la fondation après 4 années 1.5 Existence de stratégie et capitalisation des fonds 1.6 Existence de stratégie de communication et de relation publique 2.1.1 Existence du siège PNC équiper et fonctionnel 2.1.2 Existence d’un plan de formation 2.2 Nombre des associations communautaires gérant de façon durable les ressources dans les zones tampons et forets associes. 2.3 1. Nombre des initiatives socio-économiques sensibles à la conservation de la biodiversité développés; 2.3.2. Nombre de structures de cogestion fonctionnels au sein d’AP ressources opérationnels. 2.4 Existence de plan de gestion CNP

comment.narrative: 1.1Ressources humaines insuffisantes (1) 1.2 Pas de document audit et reportage transparent et internationalement reconnus 1.3 Fonds initial injecté est de 57% 1.4 Pas de dotation 1.5 Pas de stratégies pour capitaliser les fonds 2.1.1 Aucun bureau fonctionnel 2.1.2 Pas de plan de formation 2.2.1 : pas d’associations communautaires gérant de façon durable les ressources dans les zones tampons et forets associées 2.2.2 : Inexistence d’outils de supervision, suivi et évaluation adéquats au sein de l’IBAP et DGFF 2.3.1 : Pas d’initiative socio-économiques sensibles à la conservation de la biodiversité développés; 2.3.2. Nombre de structures de cogestion fonctionnels au sein d’AP ressources opérationnels 2.4 Pas de Plan de gestion

La Fondation est opérationnelle efficace et efficiente Le document pour le développement administratif existe Le système financier et fudicaire existe Le siège de l’AP est équipé et fonctionnel Le document plan de formation est disponible Quatre d’initiative socio-économiques sensibles à la conservation de la biodiversité développés; Quatre structures de cogestion fonctionnelle au sein d’AP ressources opérationnels Plan de gestion du CNP disponible

description.narrative: développer des mécanismes et des capacités de prévention des risques climatiques et de gestion des catastrophes dans les régions Nord, Est et Sud de la Guinée-Bissau, à savoir : Gabú, Bafatá, Cacheu et Quinara.
renforcer la resilience des communautés pour reduire les risques de catastrophes et accroitre la capacite d'adaptation aux changements climatiques.
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

comment.narrative: - 30 plans de Developpment Communautaires integrant la reduction des risques de cataatrophes et le changement climatique sont disponibles, - le document politique d'education national integrant la RRC et CC est formulé -la strategie nationale de la RRc et son Plan d'action sont reactualisées et disponibles
